DOC.HEAD: Daytona Beach Wants to Tone Down Spring Break
DOC.TEXT: Daytona Beach has established a spring break task force to prevent a repeat of destruction and chaos caused last March by an estimated 400,000 revelers. ``Spring break in 1989 was totally out of control,'' Mayor Larry Kelly told the Sun-Sentinel in Fort Lauderdale. ``Frankly, there was an attitude by certain businesses and public officials to let it all hang loose. And I think it was a serious mistake.'' Daytona Beach's problem sounded familiar to officials down the coast in Fort Lauderdale. They had told the spring break crowd three years ago it was no longer welcome in Fort Lauderdale. Daytona Beach began a campaign to lure the young vacationers to their city. But now, the task force will study how it might follow Fort Lauderdale's lead to tone down the partying. Last March, Daytona Beach private and public property was destroyed and visitors urinated in back yards, brawled in the streets and more. The experience prompted the establishment of the Spring Break Festival Task Force. ``The accent is on that third word because that's what we're trying to make it _ a festival instead of a free-for-all,'' said Suzanne Smith, director of special events for the Daytona Beach Chamber of Commerce. Fort Lauderdale Mayor Bob Cox once told Kelly on network television that he'd be only too glad to let Daytona Beach become the new mecca for spring break. ``He turned to me and said, `You can have them,''' the Daytona Beach mayor recalled. ``And I got them.'' City officials and business leaders in Daytona Beach eager to boost local revenues mounted expensive advertising campaigns touting their sandy shores to vacation-hungry college students no longer wanted in Fort Lauderdale. Cox said he would gladly share tips with Daytona Beach officials on Fort Lauderdale's successful steps to shed its decades-old party-time image. He said two important measures include cracking down on alcohol on the beach and erecting walls along the Strip to separate pedestrians from motorists.
